text: A good movie for the first 2/3rds of it.  The ending left us very disappointed as it didn't really tie together the main storylines.  No blame on the acting as the cast did a great job here.  It almost feels like they ran out of money and had to rush through the last 15 minutes.

Not bad, but unfortunately a potentially nice Christmas movie culminated in the heroine cheating on her blameless fiancé. Hardly an uplifting Christmas storyline, and it wasn't even necessary for the plot.
Triggering for those with sensitivity to infidelity storylines.

This had a slightly different twist on a Christmas romance. Even though there were predictable scenes, they fit in nicely. The perfect casting and wonderful acting made it easy to watch till the end. The supporting actors never over played their rolls. The only problem I had was the standing out in the cold and all the candles in the room. Could I watch again someday, yes and so it receives 5 stars.

I watched this movie and it had me sobbing—it was such a wholesome, sweet love story. I truly enjoyed it so much. The chemistry between the characters was incredible; I could feel the love through the screen. The storyline was beautiful overall. Absolutely amazing.

If you like to be manipulated, then by all means - enjoy this ham-fisted romantic, holiday, personal tragedy movie. But if you have a hard time swallowing lots of coincidences and manipulative plot devices, then walk away.
Plus, as if the contrived plot weren't enough, the two leads had very little chemistry with Barrett Doss basically sleep-walking through the movie. 
The script was an amalgamation of every Hallmark movie slapped together by some AI algorithm.
The plot is this: A rich, best-selling author learns that his mom died and has to return to his small-town home that brings back pain from his brother's death and his dad abandoning the family... during Christmas. But wait, that's only part of the story because at his family home he encounters an adopted girl, who's about to get married to a boring man, seeking information about her mom who happened to live in this house and secretly left behind a diary... oh yeah, and her birthday is coming up soon.
It's as if this writer tried to cram in as many emotional holidays, special days and childhood trauma into one story as possible. I'm surprised the girl wasn't about to give birth before graduating from college while learning that she's got cancer!
There were other subplots in this film, but they're all terribly trite. 
The problem with jamming in too many ideas into one story is that none of them felt real: the house gets cleaned up in minutes, a book is read in minutes and forgiveness is granted in minutes. Compressed time prevents the audience from feeling the real weight of an emotion.
Justin was good- if that's enough, then go for it. But on a story-level, this was good direction trying to mask the poor writing of a story that should have been a mini-series. Can't recommend.

I'm not sure what movie most of these critics watched.  The Noel Diary is a compelling movie centred around two people whose lives are missing an emotional and loving attachment to their families. 

The two main characters are special together and the development of their relationship is easy and believable

Not a romcom Christmas movie at all.  Happens to take place around Christmas and truly is a satisfying watch.  Directing, Acting, Plot in this world of wars and you know what  is a great break from the realities of life.

It’s hard to get past the fact that the entire premise of this feel good Christmas movie is an engaged woman cheating on her fiancé. The two main characters have no chemistry, yet they open up about their deepest secrets minutes into meeting each other. The backstory about the main male character’s family troubles and estranged mother makes no sense and is never fully explained. The movie was entertaining because of how ridiculous it is.

Here is the plot of this “Christmas” movie:

A happily engaged couple’s world gets torn apart when a handsome, rich, and successful author comes to town to deal with the loss of his mother. The well-intentioned betrothed woman offers to help the stranger deal with lingering family issues. At her insistence, The woman goes on a road trip with the man she just met so he can reconcile with his father.

The betrothed woman’s fiancé stays home to plan their future together and supports his fiancé’s decision to help this man he’s never met. The engaged couple remains in contact during the road trip while the woman spends numerous nights in hotels with the attractive man. The betrothed man is depicted as everything women claim they want in a relationship. Her fiancé is communicative, attentive, caring, trusting, supportive and loving. He displays no hint of insecurity or jealousy. Their relationship is presented as otherwise ideal. No underlying issues or problems between the couple are revealed. For all intents and purposes, they are happily engaged.

Little does the woman’s fiancé know she is cheating on him, sleeping with the handsome man she has known only a week. The woman comes home in time for Christmas Eve and unceremoniously dumps her fiancé for the handsome stranger. Merry Christmas.

In a cruel twist, the story is told from the betrothed woman’s point of view and presented as an uplifting holiday movie. Who approved this script? How did this movie get green-lit? Bah. Humbug!

I liked the acting in this show.  The characters were intriguing enough to keep my attention.  The end was very unsatisfying after watching the storylines evolve.  Some of the continuity was lacking -- wouldn't a Range Rover in a snow storm have defrosters and not a lot of snow on the windshield?  Does it make sense that he was having through with the fire in the fireplace, then just leaves it?  If Justin Hartley does not play the piano, it was a good hand double.  I liked this movie and might watch it again.  Or maybe not, only because of the ending.

I enjoyed this movie. The story line was unique. Having it staged around the holidays made it nostalgic. Being based on a biracial couple was a pleasing surprise. Their relationship built in such a realistic manner, that it beg for a continuation. I watched this movie a few years ago, and just came across it again. I cried at the same spots and wanted the movie to go on at the end. Critics bias clearly seen in some of the other comments.  This was a very entertaining movie.
Poorly written 1 dimensional Hollywood rubbish
Cute movie with a more original storyline.   It is a movie I would actually rewatch next holiday season, which is says a lot for me.
I’ve watched this movie several times! I just love the actors, their chemistry, the story, etc!
This movie is ok. Nothing special or creative and the acting is not good.

The Noel Diary ist eine romantische Komödie von Charles Shyer, basierend auf dem Buch The Noel Diary von Richard Paul Evans, der auch das Drehbuch schrieb…  Als ein Autor Weihnachten sein Elternhaus ausräumt, begegnet er einer Frau, die nach ihrer leiblichen Mutter sucht… Eine nette Geschichte für die Feiertage, ein herzerwärmender romantischer Weihnachtsfilm… mit einer guten, durchschnittlichen schauspielerischen Leistung…

Plot is so full of holes. We only finished the film because of a) the acting ability of its stars, and b) it was hilarious to keep pausing the film to highlight its obvious flaws. Not sure how films like this even get made. There are so many wonderful scripts out there not being produced.
Cheating is not romantic, fun or interesting to have as the turning point in what could otherwise have been a cute holiday movie.
Better than I anticipated. Ha .

Bruh… the editing of this movie is bad; slow-mo scenes, obvious stock videos, and inconsistent lighting.

It's actually a good movie to understand what not to do in making a movie…

The glossy, edited scenery makes the flaws in this movie even more apparent.

The most likeable actor is the dog. 

We have a confused, lonely writer Jake, Turner meeting Rachel (engaged to be married), who share little chemistry together.
 Rachel, the cheating fiance, is a highly unlikable character, and her doe-eyed stares and fake grin do little to convince us otherwise.


Poor writing never explains decades of estrangement between Jake and his recently deceased Mom.

The reason he didn't talk to Dad for 35+ years gets sort of explained at the end.
 
The ending is a letdown, too.

Rachel and her birth Mom Noel never meet .

Jake takes Rachel back, even though she said she does not love home and wants to stay with Alan her fiance.
What changed???
Never got explained
